content:
Biography  About Me  Mohan Nataraj, a pure mathematician, theoretical computer scientist and software developer with more than 5 years of experience from silicon valley of India Bangalore, India. I‚Äôm currently working in an early stage startup - designing and developing. I do lead myself with great confidence and believe in the following,  
 "It is by his activities and not by enjoyment that man feels he is alive. In idleness we not only feel that life is fleeting, but we also feel lifeless‚Äù -Immanuel kant    Philosophy through experience has always been my innate belief. While it is aberrant for a pure mathematician to say "I believe in GOD" my experiences in life would otherwise prove so.
My research interests include distribution in prime numbers, optimization, mathematical modeling, analysis and any programmable matter.
Two of my most fervent personal research project; I persevere on are Riemann hypothesis and computer aided drug development for CANCER.
Member of American Mathematical Society -Carleton University (2019-2020)  Member of IEEE  - Illinois Institute of Technology (2012-2020)   * _``` Member of IEEE (Illinois Tech) [2012-present]```_ --                Interests   Number Theory Graph Theory Complex Analysis Mathematical Optimization Probability & Statistics Artificial Intelligence Cancer Drug Development   Education     Master of Science in Pure Mathematics, 2019
Carleton University - (Dropped out as my mother was diagonized with metastatic breast cancer and expired on - 21/9/2020)
    Master of Science in Applied Mathematics (unconferred), 2018
Illinois Institute of Technology - Chicago, Illinois
    Master of Science in Computer Science, 2013
Illinois Institute of Technology - Chicago, Illinois
    Bachelors of Engineering in Computer Science, 2011
Visvesvaraya Technological University - Bangalore, India
      Nvidia Jetson Nano - CUDA  A.I. on GPU: running single A.I. neural network on CPU is too mainstream  Working closer to metal - SOC, parallel and distributed processing and A.I. as always been my interest especially as a   GAMER  - Nvidia GPU's  are innately exciting.
  Read to know more on how this small beast will be helpful in my projects. Read More
summary: Biography  About Me  Mohan Nataraj, a pure mathematician, theoretical computer scientist and software developer with more than 5 years of experience from silicon valley of India Bangalore, India. I‚Äôm currently working in an early stage startup - designing and developing.
title: Mohan Nataraj

content:
Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]] name = "Courses" url = "courses/" weight = 50  Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]] name = "Docs" url = "docs/" weight = 50  Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Basics of javascript language for future reference. Most of them are referenced from [w3school](https://www.w3schools.com/js/)
title: Overview

content:
2. Overview This stage is where we have a user profile for an ideal user and also this stage is the middle stage of coming up with the idea and making the idea. So we invest time in this stage and do not go to prototying or visual stage without completing this stage of the idea.  
Here we use semi-visual i.e; words and diagrams to articulate our ideas…
 Planning Testing Researching Mapping  graph LR; App-Idea-- using words-->Envision; Envision--words, maps, skteches -->Prototype;  app idea (words) -> envision (words, maps, sketches) -> prototype (experience, final design) non-visual -> semi visual -> visual
2.1. Envision : flowchart LR; mapping(Mapping content) <--> development(Developing ideas); development(Developing ideas)<-->paperprotptyping(Prototype testing); paperprotptyping(Prototype testing)<-->visualdevelopment(Wireframe & UI);   This stage we are still developing the content and ideas. We can still change things at this stage. Be more analytical and critical about what can work and what will not work? As the arrows in the flowchart indicate we can move front and back on any stage of the development until refined and accepeted to meet the required market needs  Note: here we are going to come up with different functionalities of the app i.e; for eg: add a recipe (how the user is going to add it?)
 Note: this functionality will be added later after content mapping. So that each individual feature is explained in further detail. We also need to explore more feasible tech to do certain task with ease !    In the next page we will see the content mapping.
title: 2.1. Planning - Envision

content:
According to the methods of innovation from wiki: Ideation: The Birth and Death of Ideas (Graham and Bachmann, 2004) we are working on the multiple such methods they are revolutionay idea(in terms of tech) problem solution, derivative idea and symbiotic idea.
1. Ideas & Goals : Three most important aspects are ideation, articulation and development.
1.1 Ideation: (focus, articulation, clarity & user feedback)
 Idea :  Problem statement: a simple service that users desire… ??  Problem One: to keep track of calories intake and calories burnt during exercise/day. Problem Two: to manage their food intake such as food journal and exercise journal.(replace the word journal with something else) Problem Three: to find healthy food options. Problem Four: to find trainer / training & food plan for better well being. Problem Five: emotional / mind wellness. Problem Six: Social wellness - events/community exploration.     Expand and explore : like all ideas we have alot of options, we then look at those ideas and… Refine and edit : here we look at those that are necessary or relevant.  The above two points repeated over and over again leads to a process. **: means tentaive idea and may pivot.
 Q) What makes a great user experience for you ?  easy to use. (such as signup, signin and sharing results)  very little time needed to learn or very intuitive app design required. clear icons interface design   minimalistic approach, such as keeping the navigation to just 4 pages etc…  smooth navigation or no unnecessary step required.   keep track of everything necessary for smoother transition from initial start to making it an habit [very important] clean design and consistent design (colors) classified or grouped acccordingly. not too much notification (leads to user disengagment) more of image based app  landing page is news feeds less text content   app should be fun to use.    MYFITNESS PAL : ability to set goals, target and track progress in weight or percentage. comphrensive : input food, exercis, drinks etc features workout and nothing screams at you.   NOTE: Three major points for great UX :  minimalistic approach - to get to the purpose/goal almost instantly. (usually within 3/4 - clicks) easy to use - such as navigation, icons, interface design (classified food & exercise correctly) fun to use - more image/video based, less text, enjoyable contents (quality of content rather than quantity? depends on what drives revenue.)    2. User Research Research & Development Q) WHAT DOES THE APP DO? This app has three major categories:
  Food
 keep track of food/calorie intake to reach your goal store food recipes of users. share user recipes with your community or squad. suggest better recipes, fruits, veggies… by keeping track of my taste via recipe or exercise goal or metal wellness. discover chefs - [GORBOX] **    Fitness
 keeps track of calories burnt/expenditured. maintain exercise journal (call this something else) share your progress/exercise with squad/community/social media find trainers/nutrionist are also users.  personal training diet plan/maintaince (basically nutrionist/trainer can take care of their diet) exercise plan (allow trainers/pro to create a plan for their goals)      Emotional/Inner Wellness
 suggest events or activities for the user based on their fitness goal and metal well being listening to podcast live yoga, meditation **     Q) HOW DOES IT WORK? -  How does it achieve the goal? Do research into content from competitor and see how we can do it differently Goal : is to help people keep track of their fitness level and shift to healthier eating habits so as they have better quality of life i.e; healthier life.  We use following tentative ways :-  Food  store and share recipes calculate food nutritional value suggest different food based on user taste. - suggest food replacement based on caloric values. (more delicious food)      NOTE: suggestion of food based on different criteria has 3 options they are as follows:  RECIPE: videos (youtube, IGTV) blog (inhouse, also see other partner) people who sell food via “GORBOX” (which should have indemand & subscription homefood)        FITNESS (Exercise)  store and share exercises. share daily achievements. calculate energy expenditured. suggest different exercise based on the current energy and target. suggest trainers based on fitness goal(- they also can manage food goals of client)    Emotional or Social Well-Being:  users or group can create & share events. podcasts on emotional well-being.(keep user entertained) community or group based engagment in activities.(food or fitness or yoga or infact something fun partner with brands related events)    FITNESS AND FOOD experts: - - suggest nutrionalist & trainers for food & fitness to achieve their target. - - check last point of fitness ** confusion need to check to include in Minimal viable product.   Q) WHO BENEFITS FROM IT? The clients, why are we creating this app ? for fun (need better UI/UX app), social good (improve people well-being), money (help single homemakers earn money [GORBOX])
 Users stay fit and track their calories Gym trainers, clients and fitness models Chefs/ Homemakers interested to earn money (FIT CHEFS [GORBOX])   Analyze if the last point is needed in MVP - minimal viable product    Q) WHY WOULD SOMEONE USE THIS? Goals and outcomes what the user should achieve of using this application.  Users who want to track their calories & stay fit. Chefs/homemakers who want to earn money by selling food / recipe book.   => My app lets you explore delicious healthy food & helps you keep track of your fitness.  [ Gorbox:  Tasty, healthy homecooked food for happy life ]
 one line explaination of FITCHEF.FIT:  [ My app lets you explore delicious healthy food & helps you track your fitness for better well-being ] FITCHEF.FIT - punch subline below:- This is sub-line: [ Explore Movement 4ur Body, Food 4ur Soul & Stillness 4ur Mind.]  [and dont forget to Socialize the 4ur for happy life!!]   Note: This entire document will be updated as and when we progress. This is not final !!!
title: 1. Ideation & User Research

content:
In this tutorial, I'll be specifying javascript datatypes in brief:
Data types  Primitive datatype : the datatype which does not have any additional properties and method associated with it other than the value itself.   The following are primitive in js:  string (primitive) number (64-bit) boolean undefined   JS evaluates an expression from left to right, therefore different sequence may produce different results.   var result = 10 + 4 + 'hello'; // [o/p]: result = 14hello  var result = 'hello' + 10 + 4; // [o/p]: result = hello104    - JS types are dynamic, they take on different value at different scope.  var x; [o/p]: type is undefined  x = 5;[o/p]: type is number  x = "hi";[o/p]: type is string    2. Objects : has additional properties and methods. - Object = when we initialize with a _new_ keyword as shown below  eg: var firstName = new String("John"); var age = new Number(10);    Number, Boolean can also be defined as an object as seen above. Array is an object type and it has various method.
summary:
In this tutorial, I'll be specifying javascript datatypes in brief:
Data types  Primitive datatype : the datatype which does not have any additional properties and method associated with it other than the value itself.
title: Javascript Datatypes

content:
2.2 Mapping Content and Interaction This page is mostly dedicated to writing content mapping and interaction via flowchart or sequence diagram using mermaid. For more advanced we can use other online editor’s such as draw.io
2.2.1 Mapping Content: In this section we focus only on developing the content on each page of the app. We follow the rules defined below for defining our content mapping.
RULES:  we use flowchart graphs for different pages. subgraphs to map each content of a particular page - if it requires anything. arrow heads represents moving to different page. without arrow head represents line in the same page. color codes for different elements of the flowchart will evolve as we work.   Note: more rules may be added if and when required to better represent this phase of our work.   2.2.2.1 Major components of App: The 4 major components of the applications are the following:
 Welcome page - contents Food Exercise Wellness - (Mood/Stress level)  1. Welcome Page: This is the page when the user enters, sees the welcome message and statistics for the day.
1.1 Mobile & Desktop Landing Page: flowchart LR id1(fas:fa-home Home / Main Page) --- id2(Contents - Main Page); id1 --- Food; id1 --- Exercise; id1 --- Polls; id1 --- Community; id1 --- Events; id1 --- Challenges; id1 --- Blog; subgraph Home Content id2 --- id3(Home Content); end  1.2 Mobile main page - contents flowchart RL id0[fas:fa-home Home Content] --- id100[[fas:fa-running Movement = Exercise + STEPS ]] id0 --- id101[[fas:fa-utensils Calories/Nourish/Nutrients]] id0 --- id102[[fas:fa-water Water]] id0 --- id103[[fas:fa-brain Mental wellness]]  1.2.1 Calorie / Nourish(ment) : This component is the extention of the each individual components & sub-routines of the “Home Content page”. This page gives the stats of the calorie intake.
flowchart TD id101[[ Calories/ Nourshiment/ Nutrition ]] --- id50{{fas:fa-chart-pie Donut Graph}} id101 --> id40[fas:fa-chart-line Stat Page] id40 --- idFR[fas:fa-utensils Food Reconmmendation - Chefs] id40 --- Marco-Nutrients idFR --> id20{Add Journal Button}---|YES|Todays-Journal-Page id20 --YES --> idCC[[Compute Calorie]] id20 --NO--> id42[far:fa-stop-circle stop] id40 --- id20 idCC --> idccs(fas:fa-apple-alt Compute-Engine ) idFR --> idsl[fas:fa-save Save for later fas:fa-bookmark]  1.2.2 Movement = Exercise + Steps: This component of the home content page gives the stats of calorie expenditure and steps taken from fit/apple/android devices.
flowchart TD id101[[fas:fa-running Movement = exercise + steps ]] --- id50{{fas:fa-chart-pie Donut or Sun Graph}} id101 --> id40[fas:fa-chart-line Stat Page] id101 --- idER[fas:fa-fire-alt Exercise Reconmmendation - Trainers] idER --> id20{Add Journal Button}---|YES|Todays-Journal-Page id20 --YES --> idCC[[Compute Calorie]] id20 --NO--> id42[far:fa-stop-circle stop] id40 --- id20 idCC --> idccs(fas:fa-apple-alt Compute-Engine ) idER --- idsa[fas:fa-save Save for Later fas:fa-bookmark]  1.2.3 Water: This component takes water input to make sure you are well hydrated.
 Dotted line : represents the feature may or may not be added.  flowchart TD id102[[fas:fa-water Water]] --- idwg{{ Water: widget take water input}} id102 -.- idER[ Juice Reconmmendation]  1.2.4 Mind - Wellness / Mood: In this component we take user inputs mood early morning and night, we also provide events/podcasts and activities and other aspects required for mental wellness.
flowchart TD id103[[fas:fa-brain Mental wellness]] --- id10{{Mood Widget}} id103 --- id1[Events]  2.2.2 Mapping Interaction: Here we map the user interaction with arrow heads represents the following sequence / page.
title: 2.2 Mapping Content & Interaction

content:
We initially list the following targeted users that the application will be useful for or used by mostly. We use this data to better design the application and the business model.
 Requires more user research from various to expand or strengthen the list.   1. POLITICAL  people who are a part of fit movement  health concious eco-friendly pro-active in their lifestyle    2. FUNCTIONAL  people who want to change their habits for a better well-being. (food, fitness and mind/mental)  uninformed/new to the lifestyle want to track their fitness want entertainment/ activity    3. PROFESSIONAL  people who want to use it as a professional/business tool  manage clients (nutrionalists/trainer for food and fitness) mind/mental wellness worker (yoga teachers etc…) event organizers - users and brands / venues etc… (gyms/hotels/etc) brand promotions via fitness professionals (nike/adidas/local apparels) homemakers.    4. SOCIAL  people who want to be inventive  companies/corporates being adventerous with employees social engagement / events try different tech - adventerous people    5. FINANCIAL  people who want to save money  thrifty on a budget just because it should be free.     The above mentioned are initial target audience and may increase or shorten the list as we grow or pivot !
title: 2. Audience & Rationale

title: Example Page 2

content:
3.1 Name   The name is currently decided and stays fit there.
  Mission of the application can be concluded from the previous pages of the chapter. Will elobrate on them once we are further into the process.
An idea about the mission is to basically serve best food and activity to everyone while they keep track of all the necessary nutritients in their body. This will not conduce to a better well-being but also requires other external environment to make a persons life better. We are more focused on health as in food and well-being as in physical and mental well-being.
title: 3. Naming and Mission

content:
RESEARCH PROPOSAL - self  1. Informal Introduction - This is an Aeonic research project, which is quite evolving over a period of time for the following reason:-
  The domain knowledge with respect to the subject Biology is very limited, infact quite unsubstantial with the following research feilds.
 Molecular Biology Fundamentals of Biochemisty Cell Biology Microbiology Science of Stem cell research - (seems like a promising field) Genes/Genetics and all it’s implications    I do read or have read biological technical paper’s / science papers, to see the progress with a specific field such as DNA/RNA sequencing / Genomics and I do carefully progress while establishing fundamentals of above mentioned topics.
  To know more about CRISPR  in Cancer Treatment and its Limitations follow the link below.  Read More  
     There are more aspect to study about different types of cells of the vital organs and biological activities.
summary: _This project explores latest computational tools and techniques for Cancer drug development, such as Artificial Intelligence in precision medicine etc._ _Here we work to come up with such similar algorithms for Generic drug development. - read to know more_
title: CANCER: Mathematical, Computational & Game Theoritical concepts for Drug Development

content:
1. Problem Statement In this project we build mathematical model or models to optimize (maximize) the expected profit for the next year by optimizing the delivery and stock inventory of the products between the factory, warehouse and shops, given logistics of sales for the year 2015. We further formalize the model by answering the questions in section [3] 
2. Overview  In this section we give the important points required in understanding and solving (formalizing) the problem.
2.1. The Product In this industry we have two types of products are sold. - Product 1 : Air conditioner = Pr1 - Product 2 : Heater = Pr 2 Comments: - Sales do not occur the same time. (i.e. the sales of P1 and P2 are seasonal - P2 can be assumed to be sold in Winter and P1 summer). - Amount of work and sales is constant throughout the year
2.2. Location of Resources Resources:
  Game Map Analogy - to real world :- (P: goods production, W: Amazon/Walmart Warehouse, S: shops or people to be delivered)    Two Plants P1 & P2 The plants produces both products. And production switches between the two products with out any delay Two warehouse W1 & W2 Store both products Amount of storage for each product refer section [2.4] Each vertical and horizontal distance is 1km in the grid  2.3. Sales The sales of the two products have the following constraints: - Shops are open 6 days a week - Number of shops = 20 - P1 >= 1 and P2 >= 1 for any given time of the year. - price of Pr1 = 300 euros and Pr2 = 100 euros Note : if customer does not find any one of the product then their is a penalty function. Comments : In order to generate more data we can assume that the monthly sales volume should be +/- 10% of the original sales volume for the same time period as given in sales.xls
2.4. Storage Capacity We see the storage Capacity of both the items .
   Product Warehouse 1 Warehouse 2     Product 1 650 650   Product 2 650 650    The above is weekly storage estimate based on total sales of all shops. i.e. capacity = argmax Sales(Pr1, Pr2) over 1 week. of all.
 Warehouse is expected to restock weekly. Shops restock on daily basis The storage capacity of all 20 shops are given.  Note : If demand of certain product is more than the capacity of a shop for that product, then we need more delivery from warehouse. Capacity cannot be expanded.
2.5. Delivery Tour The deliveries are done by trucks, therefore the usual path taken is from factory - warehouse - shops.
 volume of heater (Pr 2): 0.4m^3 volume of a/c (Pr 1): 0.8m^3 capacity of trucks in volume: 20m^3 cost of delivery : 1 euro per kilometer  3. Solution 3.1. Production Model  In this we try to answer the question: “How many items must be produced each day by both the plants?“ 
 From the given problem statement it is seen that there are 20 shops with 2 plants that produces goods with 2 warehouses that stores them. 
The main objective of the problem statement is to maximize the profit.
  One method to view the problem in order to maximize the profit of this market:
 is to maximize the sales given the value of the products (300 and 100 euros) for the given market constraints and minimize the transportation cost in delivery of the goods to the shops from the warehouses.     market constraints : given is to satisfy the demand of the shops with the capacity constraints, which is the warehouse capacity.
  The warehouse capacity is greater than sum of capacities of the shops.
  The demand can be derived from the sales of each of the products.
  [[Linear Optimization Model]] : Plant 1  Max 300 x[1] + 100 x[2] subject to, x[1] + x[2] ‚â§ 67600 (capacity) x[1] + x[2] ‚â• 34305 (demand) x[i] ‚â• 0 ‚àÄ i ‚àà {1,2}  Plant 2  Max 300 x[3] + 100 x[4] subject to, x[3] + x[4] ‚â§ 67600 (capacity) x[3] + x[4] ‚â• 34305 (demand) x[i] ‚â• 0 ‚àÄ i ‚àà {3,4}  x[i] represents amount of goods produced per year (a better formulation is needed will be done once I start working - again on this project)
NOTE: such as products produced per week and further deduce it to per day.
  The above two models represent where the plants satisfy the demands of shops closer to them.
  We divide the market into two where the plant 1 satisfies demand of shops 1 -10 and plant to satisfies demand of shops 11 - 20.
  The above two models represent where the plants satisfy the demands of shops closer to them. We divide the market into two where the plant 1 satisfies demand of shops 1 -10 and plant to satisfies demand of shops 11 - 20.
  3.1.2. Dantzig Wolfe Decomposition method Well from the above two linear program it is evident that we can formulate the following problem as Dantzig Wolfe Decomposition method. This is also similar to [1] where the two plants are trying to satisfy the demands of the market (coupling constraint) and each plant has its own demands (subproblem) to be solved.
3.1.3. Further Optimization: Integer or Linear Relaxtion Well both the problems need to be formulated as integer program or LP relaxation problem and then use Gomory cut algorithm to reduce it to integer solution. Note : we can also use branch and bound technique to get an integer solution.
3.1.4. Slack & surplus Variable = Stored good in warehouse Introducing a surplus variable into the demand constraint and converting it to equality (standard LP form) will give us the amount of goods that needs be stored in the warehouse. 
Example: for Plant 2 is similar as Plant 1 as shown below
Plant 1  Max 300 x[1] + 100 x[2] subject to, x[1] + x[2] + s[1] = 67600 (capacity) x[1] + x[2] - s[2] = 34305 (demand) x[i] ‚â• 0 ‚àÄ i ‚àà {1,2} where s[1] = slack, s[2] = surplus  3.2. Transportation This problem has various approach to solve this problem. One such approach is to convert the problem into a variant of network flow problem.
3.2.1 Graph theory formulation: We can formulate is as a bipartite graph such that, V = S U W, where S = {s1_v, …. s20_v} and we replicated the same at W = {s1_w,…..s20_w} we now connect the edges from s1_v to all the other vertices in partite set W except that we do not connect s1_v to s1_w since s1_v and s1_w are the same shop. Therefore d(s1_v) = 19, infact for each of the vertices in V and W.
Futher we use backward substitution method to connect all the vertices in V to warehouses w1 and w2. Similarly we to the following for the partite set W. (Note the edges in this graph is assumed to have a cost which is the shortest distance between any two vertices)
We know that each of these vertices have a demand to be satisfied, when the demand for the vertices are met we say that the vertex is saturated. The conditions for Halls matching and Konig Egervary perfect matching theorem is met in such a graph. (Note : the above also seems more of assignment problem if # of trucks = 20)
We can use a variant of network flow and matching algorithm algorithm to solve the problem. We need to saturate the vertices which is basically the demand and also we define unit flow to be 20 m^3 in volume which is the capacity of each truck. We can determine to minimize the flow so that all of the vertices are saturated.
Conclusion: The above problem can be eaisly formulated as a combination of NP -hard and NP - complete problems i.e; variant of TSP, Bin Packing/ multi knapsack problem. Here I deduce this to a polynomial time problem.
 NOTE: Necessary Improvements
  the model needs to be further improved as mentioned [[ Linear optimization model]] - [3.1] this will be done as I start working on this project again sooner… transportation model needs to be formulated into LP [3.2.1] also create .md slides…   Tools: I tried to work on Julia Optimization package and Julia light graphs. (this requires more time need to look into JULIA will be working on formulating better) some basic code I execute
mlp = Model(solver=ClpSolver()) @variable(mlp, x[1:2] >= 0) @constraint(mlp, x[1] + x[2] >= 34305) @constraint(mlp, x[1] + x[2] <= 67600) @setObjective(mlp, Max, 300*x[1] +100*x[2])  getvalue(x[1]) 67600.0 getvalue(x[2]) 0.0 getObjectiveValue(mlp) 2.028e7  REFERENCES: [1] Introduction to Linear Optimization, by Dimitris Bertsimas and John Tsitsiklis. Athena Scientic, 1997, 608 pp ISBN 1-886529-19-1 [2] Click on pdf for official problem statement by FFJM GAME
summary: French Federation of Mathematical Games (2018): _problem statement given on real-world problems that can be modelled as Non-Polynomial time and Polynomial time algorithms_.
title: Math Modelling Competition : NP-Complete and P Time

content:
This is pretty cool talk by Charles Stross, given at Chaos Computer Club congression this talk reflects my opinion or views on current world of corporates, startups, artificial intelligence (referred by speaker as corporate AI and computerized AI) and one ridiculed CEO or lets say more than one [:P]. You can also find reason’s on why I quit facebook or hated it in the first place.
The talk starts by saying on how prediction 3 centuries back or even a century back was possible to do accurately. Which infact reminds me of what my astrologer threw at me when I asked him where I will exactly be in 5 years [üòÑ]. Further the speaker talks about Artificial Intelligence singularity (computerized), infact you can giggle on when the speaker says @ 7:30 “if we created an AI equivalent of human mind it would be sitting on a couch and watching super bowl all day”, I’m sure to say this is one of the least obnoxious way anyone can put it knowing what we human’s are capable of doing or the way we live in 21st century.
To continue on the speaker says “AI as self optimizing tool which defy human comprehension”, which is quite absolutely right, and while the comparison of airplane to seagull makes us want to giggle, we can also wonder if our education system & professor’s are doing good enough to produce skillful people or are we just about the grades ?
 Well, continuing on the next statement that caught my attention when the speaker says “history is useful for so much more than that” funny on how forget our past in speaker’s words “our personal memory don’t span very long at all”, haha! in fact, every 5 year’s we vote. [:D]
The speaker further goes on to talk about paper clip maximizer theory of artificial intelligence and one of the CEO that supports it. Which to me seems funny on how people see things especially some the most renowned CEO’s. Just WOW!!! The speakers quirky comments are quite joyful and his correlation to corporations and governmental organization are so damn true.
While I can go on for quite a bit about this talk. I would like to keep the writing short and let you watch the video. This is more of an opinionated talk and is very entertaining. The speaker not so surprisingly also talks about the corporations like Facebook - its role in the society and developers building app’s that gets people addicted to them.
The speaker Charles Stross quite greatly articulates my views and reasons why one should stay away from social media and as well smart phone as much as they can.
I hope you enjoy this video.
summary: This is pretty cool talk by Charles Stross, given at Chaos Computer Club congression this talk reflects my opinion or views on current world of corporates, startups, artificial intelligence (referred by speaker as corporate AI and computerized AI) and one ridiculed CEO or lets say more than one [:P].
title: Dude You Broke the Future

content:
Whilst “Bridges” are built to span through obstacles, the preceding statement was quite erring in the city of K√∂nigsberg in Prussia (now Kaliningrad, Russia) during the 18th century. Here we talk about the inception of Graph Theory, it’s application to the real world problems and a famous puzzle asked during my childhood. The blog also contain a pretty good talk given by a math student below in Chaos Computer Club congression.
During the 18th century in the city of K√∂nigsberg the land masses were connected by seven bridges. The problem or challenge in the city was to walk or traverse through the seven bridges only once, i.e; to walk atmost only once on all the bridges. While the challenge was talk of the town during the period, we show on how Leonhard Euler approached the problem that actually gave rise to “Graph Theory”.
  left to right city of K√∂nigsberg converted into graph (graph theory)   The right most part of the image shows on how the land masses and bridges are converted into graph theoretic notation. The land masses are represented by a circle or commonly called “Node or Vertex” and the line connecting two nodes is called an “Edge”. An edge commonly defines a relationship between two nodes and they always connect two nodes. The last term to know is degree of a node which is actually the number of edges or lines incident on a node or vertex. Now since we got the basics of Graph Theory before diving into Euler’s solution I would like share the childhood puzzle, well that’s why the whole blog started out to be.
While in the 90’s and early 2000’s my city Bangalore or more infamously known as Garden City or Land of 1000 lakes was absolutely a great city & time to grow and have fun (name it from sport, education to being a cool kid you had it all). whoever you were one of the famous puzzle or challenge thrown at us was to draw the below image without lifting your pen or pencil and most importantly you cannot pass over the line already drawn i.e; you cannot pass a line twice.
  figure to draw (familiar?)   While the above can be converted into graph theoretical notation, just as how Leonhard Euler did it. Well here is how, we can convert it by drawing circle or vertices or nodes at the four corners of the square and consider the line joining them as edges (curved lines are also edges). Now if you have tried solving the above you know that it is not possible to complete the following diagram, but almost possible well you may just miss one edge out of 10 (try). The explanation here is quite easy, I shall let you think with a hint “degree of vertex” well I hope that you paid attention to that term above to be more precise atleast two vertices or nodes or circles should have what number of degree’s (odd or even)? Hmmm!! Well did that just reveal the answer, hope not!!. But hey, just so you did not get the above story that’s absolutely fine see the video below to know more about Euler’s solution to K√∂nigsberg problem:
    I hope you got it now, oh well there is always something about old white men and being genius got to blame Einstein. [üòõ] For more entertainment and want to know more about graph theory and video games as “we cool kids” love playing PC games. Here is a video from Chaos Computer Club
 The above video does have some very cool content if you are into topology, . The real world application of graph theory is quite immense due to its simplicity, it ranges from waking across the 18th century bridges to current navigation technology, yep that’s right google maps does use it. You can also use it for scheduling airplanes, project management, production management and hey what’s more important than scheduling your life ?
 update better links if exists on internet later Wiki - Seven Bridges Wiki - Topology
summary: Whilst “Bridges” are built to span through obstacles, the preceding statement was quite erring in the city of K√∂nigsberg in Prussia (now Kaliningrad, Russia) during the 18th century. Here we talk about the inception of Graph Theory, it’s application to the real world problems and a famous puzzle asked during my childhood.
title: Childhood Puzzle Solved
